Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Tool to determine if a .nupkg has valid Microsoft metadata" (#7834) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is a new version of https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/7000. I did this so that I can leave `jver-verify` as-is, which is hard-coded into Arcade:
https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/blob/a68b528ad1d0305f55c4fbdc977ebb0c02cfcc19/eng/common/post-build/nuget-validation.ps1#L12

Given that Arcade is using this in their official pipeline, it's time to merge this and get them to switch to a build that is properly signed and published by the NuGet team. The current dependency is precarious since the binary they are using is built by me and not published by the NuGet team.
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Jver.VerifyMicrosoftPackage/0.0.1-beta

We will be providing the tool as-is (no behavior changes).

We will be providing the tool as-is (no behavior changes).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Not able to add package from file" (#7833) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### For issues regarding the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), file a bug on [NuGet Home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues).

### Describe the bug
I am trying very basic demo explained at https://softchris.github.io/pages/dotnet-core.html#download-and-use-a-package-from-the-nuget-repository
As explained in the demo, I am trying to add Newtonsoft.Json package to my project. I am behind the proxy and not able to download the package from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json. However, I have downloaded the package manually and attempting to add it to project. 

Get-PackageSource

Name                             ProviderName     IsTrusted  Location
----                             ------------     ---------  --------
nuget.org                        NuGet            False      https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
**NewtonSoft.Json**                  NuGet            True       **D:\mypoc\ignite\demo1\library\newtonsoft.json.12.0.3.nupkg**
PSGallery                        PowerShellGet    False      https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2


### To Reproduce

Project structure:
02/04/2020  12:27 PM    <DIR>          .
02/04/2020  12:27 PM    <DIR>          ..
02/04/2020  11:53 AM    <DIR>          bin
02/04/2020  12:21 PM               135 library.csproj
02/04/2020  11:57 AM         2,596,051 newtonsoft.json.12.0.3.nupkg
02/04/2020  11:53 AM    <DIR>          obj
02/04/2020  11:54 AM               183 Thing.cs
               3 File(s)      2,596,369 bytes
               4 Dir(s)  294,733,180,928 bytes free


 dotnet add library package Newtonsoft.Json

### Expected behavior
It should add the package

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15668995/73727543-b43f5e00-4757-11ea-8652-66f7159da4f6.png)


### Additional context
Add any other context about the problem here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Gallery should reject packages with duplicate dependencies" (#7714) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
These packages can't be opened by some tools (NuGet Package Explorer) and the semantics of a duplicate dependency are undefined.

For example:
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Paket.Core/5.237.1

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/69655106-bf289480-102a-11ea-9368-ee717e540b9b.png)

These duplicate dependencies became an array with two items for the dependency range, which is invalid and caused Catalog2Lucene to get blocked.

The following query shows cases of this. There are very few.

```sql
SELECT pr.Id, p.NormalizedVersion, p.Created, p.PackageStatusKey, pd.Id AS DependencyId, pd.TargetFramework, COUNT(*) AS [Count]
FROM PackageRegistrations pr 
INNER JOIN Packages p ON pr.[Key] = p.PackageRegistrationKey
INNER JOIN PackageDependencies pd ON p.[Key] = pd.PackageKey
GROUP BY pr.Id, p.NormalizedVersion, p.Created, p.PackageStatusKey, pd.Id, pd.TargetFramework
HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT pd.VersionSpec) > 1
ORDER BY p.Created
```

Id | NormalizedVersion | Created | PackageStatusKey | DependencyId | TargetFramework | Count
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
Paket.Core | 5.237.1 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | Newtonsoft.Json | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.1 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | FSharp.Core | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.1 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | System.Net.Http.WinHttpHandler | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.1 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | System.Security.Cryptography.ProtectedData | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.2 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | FSharp.Core | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.2 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | Newtonsoft.Json | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.2 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | System.Security.Cryptography.ProtectedData | netstandard2.0 | 2
Paket.Core | 5.237.2 | 11/26/2019 | 0 | System.Net.Http.WinHttpHandler | netstandard2.0 | 2

It seems like this happened at least once before considering the catalog record:
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/data/2016.02.21.11.06.01/dingu.generic.repo.ef7.1.0.0-beta2.json

I think we hard deleted that package ID and version!

/cc @zhhyu

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "credentials not used" (#6655) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,
we are willing to use artifactory as nuget storage. We do have there private repo which requires login (certificate chain ends with self signed cert).
Nuget.exe is not able to download/install package. Neither restore.
nuget install <packagename>
Output:

  C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\

Installing package 'packagename' to 'c:\work\tsu'.

Unable to find package 'packagename'

Interesting is push works fine!
nuget.exe push Newtonsoft.Json.11.0.1\Newtonsoft.Json.11.0.1.nupkg -Source etb
Pushing Newtonsoft.Json.11.0.1.nupkg to 'https://servername.com/artifactory/api/nuget/tsupocnuget'...
  PUT https://servername.com/artifactory/api/nuget/tsupocnuget/
  Created https://servername.com/artifactory/api/nuget/tsupocnuget/ 2305ms
Your package was pushed.


Repo work fine, see test by curl:
CASE 1 - without usr/passwd

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Pack should emit warning when a targets  file is included in build/buildCrossTargeting folder with a name different than package id." (#6664) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Details about Problem
VS 15.7.0 Preview 1.0
NuGet.exe version: 4.5.1.4879

### Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a package using `nuget.exe pack <packageName>.nuspec` containing an arbitrary `.targets` file.
2. Try to install the package into a .NET Core 2.0 project
3. Inspect the contents of `project.assets.json` file

### Result

The target file from the package is not referenced. 

While this behavior is by design it'd be better to emit a warning per included target file if it doesn't match certain criteria. The warning can be generated by pack as well as install command.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "msbuild /restore support for all NuGet use cases" (#6410) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Background
As new .NET project types (e.g. .NET Core, among others) are introduced, newer versions of NuGet are required to understand the project type and accompanying target framework. In Visual Studio, this is fine because the VS update that brings the new project types also brings new versions of NuGet libraries that can restore packages for these project types.

VSTS builds are unable to provide this same symmetry because we are unable to use those built-in NuGet libraries, and instead call NuGet.exe or dotnet.exe directly to do restore. This causes issues when the version of NuGet used to restore is too old to work with one or more of the projects in the user's solution. We want to avoid this issue by using the new msbuild /restore functionality, which relies solely on the installed copy of MSBuild, which in turn matches the version of Visual Studio installed on the build agents. This will mean that agents can build new project types as soon as they're updated to a new version of Visual Studio.

## Ask
However, msbuild /restore currently only works for .NET Core/PackageRef projects. We'd like to have its functionality extended to support both .NET paradigms (Framework/packages.config is missing). Once that's done, we can simplify the VSTS build templates for .NET project to use this built-in restore capability and avoid hard-to-debug build errors during the restore step.

## Related issues
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5997
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/6039
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5236
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5164
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5065
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/145862/build-nuget-restore-private-feed.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/158828/nuget-restore-on-private-agent-always-using-v41.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/100882/nuget-restore-fails-after-aspnet-core-20-migration.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/32997/hosted-agent-2017-with-nuget-35.html

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "msbuild /restore support for all NuGet use cases" (#6410) at NuGet/Home

## Background
As new .NET project types (e.g. .NET Core, among others) are introduced, newer versions of NuGet are required to understand the project type and accompanying target framework. In Visual Studio, this is fine because the VS update that brings the new project types also brings new versions of NuGet libraries that can restore packages for these project types.

VSTS builds are unable to provide this same symmetry because we are unable to use those built-in NuGet libraries, and instead call NuGet.exe or dotnet.exe directly to do restore. This causes issues when the version of NuGet used to restore is too old to work with one or more of the projects in the user's solution. We want to avoid this issue by using the new msbuild /restore functionality, which relies solely on the installed copy of MSBuild, which in turn matches the version of Visual Studio installed on the build agents. This will mean that agents can build new project types as soon as they're updated to a new version of Visual Studio.

## Ask
However, msbuild /restore currently only works for .NET Core/PackageRef projects. We'd like to have its functionality extended to support both .NET paradigms (Framework/packages.config is missing). Once that's done, we can simplify the VSTS build templates for .NET project to use this built-in restore capability and avoid hard-to-debug build errors during the restore step.

## Related issues
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5997
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/6039
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5236

- https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5065
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/145862/build-nuget-restore-private-feed.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/158828/nuget-restore-on-private-agent-always-using-v41.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/100882/nuget-restore-fails-after-aspnet-core-20-migration.html
- https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/32997/hosted-agent-2017-with-nuget-35.html

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "list -IncludeDelisted does not seem to work" (#6234) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`nuget list -IncludeDelisted` does not seem to work anywhere (v.4.4.1.4656). I have tried it with NuGet.Server 2.11.3 and 3.0.0. As well as `-allversion` and/or `-prerelease`.

Looking at `/nuget/Packages()` shows the delisted packages.

So `-IncludeDelisted` is generally not supported? So why does this switch exist at all?

Related closed issue #5896
Related NuGet.Server Issue [https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5066](url)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Git tags corresponding to nuget versions for `NuGet.BuildTasks`" (#6135) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I can't find any git tag corresponding to the nuget versions released for `NuGet.BuildTasks`. Is there another
way to find the commit hash used for building a particular nuget version?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Get zero errors or warnings when a version number in a PackageReference is invalid" (#5531) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS version (if appropriate): Version 15.3.0 Preview 4.0 [26629.0.d15rel]

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

``` XML
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.1</TargetFramework>
    <GiveMeAVersion>9.0.1</GiveMeAVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>

    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version=" '$(GiveMeAVersion)' " />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

## Expected:
An error about invalid version number in the Error List (it has extraneous single quotes).

## Actual:
No error in the error list, but the dependency node show an warning icon on the package with zero information as to the issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "restore should support multiple project files targeting same baseintermediateobjdir" (#4850) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm running the latest VS2017 release and dotnet 1.0.0 on windows 10 x64 stable. I came across a potential bug with dotnet restore.

Here is the a link the source:
https://github.com/exceptionless/Exceptionless.Net/tree/9614d2bc1d2cb949945d05ff4dbf0d8bed0738f0

I have to have signed nuget packages so my initial goal was to have my shared library have a project.csproj and a project.signed.csproj in the same folder. Then in depending packages (projectc) have a msbuild condition based on the state of `SignAssembly` and reference the correct csproj file and set the new package id. This failed because dotnet restore creates the lock file without signing. So when I build projectc it works, when I do a second pass on projectc with a msbuild property set to enable signing it would compile the first signed target framework and then blow up with a crazy error. I have sense abandoned this approach and went for a new csproj and folder per signed project as I couldn't get around this.. I no longer have the error message but it should be simple to reproduce.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Provide auto-restore notification mechanism" (#4483) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: NuGet partners requested to receive a notification when auto-restore is completed. Number of VS automation flows depends on restore information/packages availability. Design and implement public API for sending such notifications.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore output in minimal verbosity is confusing and not informative enough" (#4375) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

In minimal verbosity output is just this:

Restoring NuGet packages...
Time Elapsed: 00:00:02.5866682
========== Finished ==========


- what project was restored?
- was restore successful or did it fail?

If we don't print even a restore result - output is just useless.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tokens are not being replaced when pacakging NETStandard libraries" (#4052) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 3.5.0.1938
dotnet.exe --version (if appropirate):
VS version (if appropriate):
OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win2012r2 v9600
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1. Create a NETStandard 1.5 library in VS2015
2. Add a .nuspec file using tokens like $id$, $title$, $description$, $version$, $author$
3. Fill out the appropriate attributes (AssemblyTitle, ...) in AssemblyInfo.cs
4. Build the project in Release
5. Create package using something like:
  nuget.exe pack ClassLibrary1.csproj -OutputDirectory "\temp" -Properties Configuration=Release -IncludeReferencedProjects -Verbosity detailed

## Other suggested things
We do use a shared file for some assembly info called GlobalAssemblyInfo.cs, but that does not seem to matter.

### Verbose Logs
Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbose | etc...)

NuGet Version: 3.5.0.1938
Attempting to build package from 'ClassLibrary1.csproj'.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '14.0' from 'C:\Program Files (x86
)\MSBuild\14.0\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific
 version of MSBuild.
Packing files from 'C:\Projects\ClassLibrary1\ClassLibrary1\bin\Release'.
Add file 'C:\Projects\ClassLibrary1\ClassLibrary1\bin\Release\ClassLibrary1.dll'
 to package as 'lib\netstandard1.5\ClassLibrary1.dll'
WARNING: Description was not specified. Using 'Description'.
WARNING: Author was not specified. Using 'Nick'.

Id: ClassLibrary1
Version: 1.0.0
Authors: Nick
Description: Description
Dependencies: Microsoft.NETCore.Portable.Compatibility [1.0.1, ), NETStandard.Li
brary [1.6.0, )

Added file '[Content_Types].xml'.
Added file '_rels/.rels'.
Added file 'ClassLibrary1.nuspec'.
Added file 'lib/netstandard1.5/ClassLibrary1.dll'.
Added file 'package/services/metadata/core-properties/37ce14818efa492f9593bff283
74710a.psmdcp'.

Successfully created package '\temp\ClassLibrary1.1.0.0.nupkg'.

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

[ClassLibrary1.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/627547/ClassLibrary1.zip)
